description:
Keroro is a frog-like alien sent from his home planet on a mission to conquer Earth. But when his cover is blown, his battalion abandons him and he ends up in the home of the Hinata family. There, he's forced to do household chores and sleep in a dark basement that was once supposedly a prison cell haunted by the ghost of an innocent girl. He even spends his free time assembling Gundam model kits. During his stay, Keroro meets up with subordinates who were also stranded during their failed invasion.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Ninja
tags.description: Prominently features Japanese warriors traditionally trained in espionage, sabotage and assasination.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Butler
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a butler.

node.description:
__Hobbies:__ All types of sport

[Profile (Osawa Inc)](https://osawa-inc.co.jp/men/nakatajouji/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/joujinakata123)

[Official Website](http://www.tiffanygrant.net/)

Tiffany Lynn Grant is an American voice actress who is known for her English-dubbing work with the former ADV Films on such anime films and television series as Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which she voiced the character Asuka Langley Soryu. Grant is also known for portraying Nojiko in One Piece, Altena in Noir, and Ryoko Subaru in Martian Successor Nadesico. Although appearing in ADV titles, she was an independent contractor, not an ADV employee. Grant currently works at FUNimation and Seraphim Digital.

Grant enjoyed her role as Neon Genesis Evangelion's Asuka so much that she briefly reprised the character in the radio plays and fan-produced anime derived from the fanfiction series Neon Genesis Evangelion: R, as well as cosplaying as Asuka (in Asuka's familiar red EVA-02 plugsuit and her school uniform) at anime conventions.

She was married to [Matt Greenfield](https://anilist.co/staff/101497/), director, co-founder of ADV and also a voice actor. They divorced on January 4, 2018.

[Blog](http://koyap.jugem.jp/) | [Agency Profile](https://tsf-official.com/talent/takehito-koyasu/)

Koyasu is the most prolific voice actor in the industry, having been credited for over 700 roles as of April 2022.

Growing up, Koyasu skipped out on going to school to watch movies at home because he wanted to become an actor. It wasn’t until later that he became interested in voice acting after having seen [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/). After graduation he entered a voice acting school. In 1988, he made his voice acting debut, and got his first regular role a year later voicing [Gai](https://anilist.co/character/13374/) in [Tenkuu Senki Shurato](https://anilist.co/anime/2113/).

Though having voiced more characters in the medium than anyone else, he is probably most known for his role as [Dio Brando](https://anilist.co/character/4004/) in [JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure](https://anilist.co/anime/14719/). He has stated that he likes playing villainous characters.

Koyasu has taken over many of [Kaneto Shiozawa](https://anilist.co/staff/95424/)’s roles after Shiozawa’s passing.

Father of [Kouki Koyasu](https://anilist.co/staff/219102/).

__Non-Anime Roles:__

- Olivert Reise Arnor - The Legend of Heroes Series (VG)
- More - Metaphor: ReFantazio (VG)
- Mustang - Goddess of Victory: Nikke (VG)

__Height__: 154 cm
__Hobbies__: watching professional wrestling

Was married to [Kouji Tsujitani](https://anilist.co/staff/95427) until his death.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ccarrollbeard) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/colleen.clinkenbeardvoiceactress)

An American voice actress and theatre actress, working mainly in the commercial and dubbing industries. She has also served as ADR director, line producer, and script writer for several anime titles for Funimation.

She gave birth to her first son, Rhodes Vandelo Carroll, on September 4, 2014.

edges.role: Theme Song Performance (OP8, OP10, OP11, ED4, ED12, ED14)

node.description: [Profile](http://little-portal.com/profile/kozakura-etsuko/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/alittlealittle) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/kozaetu/)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/marchimark) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/jamiemarchi/)

An American voice actress, ADR director, and script writer who works for Funimation and Sentai Filmworks. She grew up in Oklahoma and graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a bachelor's degree in theater, starting her professional acting career in 2000. She married fellow actor Sean T. Perez on August 8, 1999, and they divorced on November 21, 2005. Jamie has two step-daughters. Her younger half-brother, [Jean-Luc Hester](https://anilist.co/staff/104094), is also a voice actor.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/marchimark) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/jamiemarchi/)

An American voice actress, ADR director, and script writer who works for Funimation and Sentai Filmworks. She grew up in Oklahoma and graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a bachelor's degree in theater, starting her professional acting career in 2000. She married fellow actor Sean T. Perez on August 8, 1999, and they divorced on November 21, 2005. Jamie has two step-daughters. Her younger half-brother, [Jean-Luc Hester](https://anilist.co/staff/104094), is also a voice actor.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/satojumichi) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤順一)

Junichi Satou is a Japanese anime director, best known for working on shoujo-based anime and in the magical girl genre. He was formerly associated with [TYO Animations](https://anilist.co/studio/333/), formerly known as [Hal Film Maker](https://anilist.co/studio/34/).

Satou’s first major work was directing the first, and a portion of the second season of [Sailor Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/530/) for [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), after which he handed the position over to [Kunihiko Ikuhara](https://anilist.co/staff/100082/), although he continued to storyboard and direct episodes for the later seasons. Satou later went on to co-direct [Ojamajo Doremi](https://anilist.co/anime/350/) alongside [Takuya Igarashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105087/), as well as the critically acclaimed [Princess Tutu](https://anilist.co/anime/721/). Satou served as chief director for long-runner [Sgt. Frog](https://anilist.co/anime/516/), and in recent years has become more known for his iyashikei works such as [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477/) and [Tamayura](https://anilist.co/anime/9055/).

He's married to [Yasuno Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/144094/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"

**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/mill_sister)** | **[Website (blog)](https://blog.goo.ne.jp/gooussy)**

Kiyoko Sayama is a Japanese director, episode director, animation director and storyboard artist.

Married to [Tetsuya Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/101548/Tetsuya-Kumagai).

Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/267367124) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/kiyo_723/)

JAM Project ("JAM" standing for "Japan Animationsong Makers") is an anime music genre (or anison) "supergroup" based in Japan, originally founded on July 19, 2000 by famous 1970s theme song artist Ichirou Mizuki. The group is composed of many vocal artists well known in the genre; aside from the many anime and video game theme songs that this group has performed together, each member is famous for their own solo performances of anime-related music.  As a group, they are perhaps best known for their themes for the Super Robot Wars series of video games.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/jnordell)

He is known for his work on Sands of Destruction (2008), The Tower of DRUAGA: The Aegis of URUK (2008) and One Piece (1999).
The brother of voice actress, [Brina Palencia](https://anilist.co/staff/95659/Brina-Palencia).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/64664693)

Yamamoto's interest in working in the anime industry piqued in high school after realizing how noticeable the difference in episodes were depending on the episode director in charge. One of his favourites shows included [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/).

In the late '80s, he joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant after finding out that it's how many of the studio's directors started off. There he met and studied under [Shuuji Iuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/115833/) on his shows [Madou King Granzort](https://anilist.co/anime/2818/) and [Mashin Eiyuuden Wataru](https://anilist.co/anime/4807/). Then after having gone freelance he got his first shot as a director as one of the three unit directors on Iuchi's [Ranma ½ film](https://anilist.co/anime/418/) in 1991.

In 2001, Yamamoto made his debut as a series director on [Shiawase Sou no Okojo-san](https://anilist.co/anime/2934/), soon after which he worked as the first director of the long-running [Keroro Gunsou](https://anilist.co/anime/516/). In 2006 he directed the well-received [NHK ni Youkoso!](https://anilist.co/anime/1210/)

More recent directorial works of his include [Yama no Susume](https://anilist.co/anime/14355/) and [Shounen Maid](https://anilist.co/anime/21321/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/64664693)

Yamamoto's interest in working in the anime industry piqued in high school after realizing how noticeable the difference in episodes were depending on the episode director in charge. One of his favourites shows included [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/).

In the late '80s, he joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as a production assistant after finding out that it's how many of the studio's directors started off. There he met and studied under [Shuuji Iuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/115833/) on his shows [Madou King Granzort](https://anilist.co/anime/2818/) and [Mashin Eiyuuden Wataru](https://anilist.co/anime/4807/). Then after having gone freelance he got his first shot as a director as one of the three unit directors on Iuchi's [Ranma ½ film](https://anilist.co/anime/418/) in 1991.

In 2001, Yamamoto made his debut as a series director on [Shiawase Sou no Okojo-san](https://anilist.co/anime/2934/), soon after which he worked as the first director of the long-running [Keroro Gunsou](https://anilist.co/anime/516/). In 2006 he directed the well-received [NHK ni Youkoso!](https://anilist.co/anime/1210/)

More recent directorial works of his include [Yama no Susume](https://anilist.co/anime/14355/) and [Shounen Maid](https://anilist.co/anime/21321/).

Tokyo, Japan (1997 – present)  POLYSICS is a Japanese new wave/synth pop/punk/rock band, hailing from Tokyo.  Discography:  · A.D.S.R.M!  - 1999 · Neu - 2000 · Eno - 2001 · For Young Electric Pop - 2002 · National P - 2003 · Now Is the Time! - 2005  · Karate House - 2007  · We Ate the Machine - 2008 · Absolute POLYSICS - 2009 · Oh! No! It's Heavy Polysick!!! - 2011 · Weeeeeeeeee!!! - 2012

He is usually an ADR Engineer but sometimes can take the spotlight by singing theme songs, He sings the ending theme to Ouran High School Host Club, The fourth ending to Dragon Ball GT and most recently ending 8 of One Piece    A native of Lansing, Michigan. At the age of 19, he left the country to study in Japan(not in the military). When he returned to the USA, he was exposed to acappella music at Southwestern Christian College. he began singing and performing acappella music at SwCC, continued at Harding University, and then with The Firemen on the Acappella Label. Now he has his own album and support uplifting uses of acappella music So the heart of my days is dedicated to the recording, writing, and performing of Acappella music.
